title: Cloud Storage Cost Calculator (AWS vs Azure vs Google)

seo.title: Cloud Storage Cost Calculator | AWS S3 vs Azure vs GCP
seo.description: Stop overpaying for cloud storage. Compare costs across AWS S3, Azure Blob, and Google Cloud Storage. Find the best price for Hot, Cool, and Archive tiers.

summary: Cloud pricing is notoriously complex. This tool cuts through the noise to give you a side-by-side cost comparison for your specific data needs.

faq.a: Egress is data leaving the cloud. It's often the 'hidden tax' of cloud storage. Moving data IN is usually free; moving data OUT to the internet costs money.

faq.q: What is the difference between Hot, Cool, and Archive?
faq.a:
**Hot:** Fast access, higher storage cost, lower access fees. Best for active websites.
**Cool:** Slower access (milliseconds), lower storage cost, higher access fees. Best for backups.
**Archive:** Slowest access (minutes/hours), lowest storage cost, highest retrieval fees. Best for regulatory compliance.

faq.q: Does this include API Request costs?
faq.a: This basic calculator focuses on Storage + Egress, which typically make up 80-90% of the bill for most use cases. API costs (PUT/GET requests) are highly variable and excluded here for simplicity.

article.heading: The Cloud Pricing Trap
article.body:
Cloud storage looks cheap on paper. 'Only $0.02 per GB!' sounds like a steal compared to buying hard drives. But the bill shock comes from three sources:
1.  **Volume:** 100 TB is 100,000 GB. That $0.02 adds up to $2,000/month.
2.  **Egress:** If you serve that data to users, you pay for every byte that leaves the data center.
3.  **Tier Mismatch:** Storing archival data in a 'Hot' tier is like renting a penthouse apartment for your old cardboard boxes.

article.heading: Choosing the Right Tier
article.body:
*   **AWS S3 Standard / Azure Hot / GCP Standard:** Use this for data accessed daily or weekly. Examples: Website images, active documents, streaming media.
*   **AWS S3-IA / Azure Cool / GCP Nearline:** Use this for data accessed monthly. Examples: Monthly backups, older project files.
*   **AWS Glacier / Azure Archive / GCP Archive:** Use this for data accessed yearly or never. Examples: 7-year tax records, legal compliance logs. *Warning: Retrieval can take hours and costs extra.*

article.heading: The Multi-Cloud Strategy
article.body: Smart CTOs don't just pick one provider; they arbitrage. You might keep your compute on AWS but store your heavy media files on a cheaper alternative like Wasabi or Backblaze B2 (which often have $0 egress fees). Use this calculator to see if the 'Big 3' are charging you a premium.
